title: About
text:
#Authors Arielle COHEN TANUGI-CARRESSE is a PhD Candidate in Economics at Université Paris Nanterre and Research Assistant with the “Management in Innovative Health” at EDHEC Business School. Her research focuses on health economics and policy evaluation, particularly how economic shocks affect the health of aging populations in Europe. French-American, she has academic experience in both France and the United States. She can be contacted at arielle.cohen
Paul SERVAIS is a PhD Candidate in political science (comparative politics) in the Center for European and Comparative Politics of Sciences Po. His research analyses the electoral impacts of climate change’s consequences in France and Western Europe, with a particular focus on territorial cleavages (urban-rural, center-periphery). His work combines quantitative and qualitative research methods.

title: Methods for Research and Policy Evaluation
text:
This website aims to support the class ‘Methods for Research and Policy Evaluation’, thaught in the school of Public Affairs of Sciences Po.
The objective of this course is to introduce quantitative methods for causal inference, relying on mathematical formalization and applying them to concrete research situations. Students will learn how to handle data - assembling a dataset, cleaning it, and preparing it for quantitative analysis. The methods covered will include a review of linear models (simple and multiple regressions) and nonlinear models (probit, logit), before moving on to the core of the course: causal inference, namely DiD, RDD, and IV (2SLS, 2SRI). Each session will be divided equally between the presentation of methods and their mathematical formulation, and in-class exercises designed to help students master the associated coding techniques. The final goal is to replicate a scientific article that applies one or more of these methods, enabling students to develop technical skills useful for research or for the quantitative evaluation of public policies. Another objective is to cultivate critical thinking regarding the strengths and limitations of such research methods. It is therefore particularly well suited for students who wish to develop their skills in computer science, mathematics, and quantitative research methods.
